item.title: Abu Dhabi’s State Oil Company Looks Beyond Oil
item.description: Having reshaped the company, Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber wants to expand internationally, particularly in natural gas, chemicals and renewables.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed and Natalie Naccache
item.media:description: Sultan Ahmed Al Jaber has helped put ADNOC, Abu Dhabi’s state oil company, on the map as a global deal maker.

item.title: Court Rules Against Justice Dept. Search of Reporter’s Computers
item.description: The judge said the court itself would search the devices, which were seized from a Washington Post reporter’s home last month.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: The courthouse for the Eastern District of Virginia in Alexandria, where a judge rejected an “unsupervised, wholesale” search by the federal government.

item.title: Wayve, an A.I. Driverless Car Start-Up in Europe, Raises $1.2 Billion
item.description: The London-based company is building a system that uses artificial intelligence to power autonomous vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: New funding values Wayve at $8.6 billion.

item.title: Pentagon Gives Anthropic an Ultimatum Over the Company’s A.I. Model
item.description: Anthropic insists on limits on how its technology is used and could be labeled a supply chain risk if it fails to accept the military’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth summoned the chief executive of Anthropic to Washington for a meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: Paramount Raises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery said Paramount’s new offer of $31 a share could lead to a “superior proposal” to the deal it signed with Netflix.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount previously offered $30 a share to acquire Warner Bros. Discovery.

item.title: Senator Blumenthal Opens Inquiry Into Iran Transactions on Binance
item.description: Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut sent a letter to Binance asking about the flow of $1.7 billion from accounts on the crypto exchange to Iranian entities.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Forsythe
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a letter to Binance, Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut asked for records about the company’s dealings with two Hong Kong entities identified by the exchange’s investigators as the origin of the transfers to Iran.

item.title: House Narrowly Rejects Air Safety Bill After Pentagon Opposition
item.description: A move to swiftly pass the bill failed by a single vote. It would have required aircraft to carry technology that officials said might have prevented a midair collision near Washington last year.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian
item.category: Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bill’s failure upends the debate around how to respond to last year’s fatal crash between a military helicopter and a commercial jet over the Potomac River.

item.title: Averted Midair Collision Shows Importance of Air Safety Act, Backers Say
item.description: The legislation’s advocates say a close call between two private planes near Teterboro, N.J., on Feb. 13 underscored how collision prevention technology could save lives.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly and Karoun Demirjian
item.media:credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images
item.media:description: A Learjet corporate aircraft carrying eight people to Teterboro Airport in New Jersey was forced to to descend quickly to avoid a midair collision on Feb. 13.

item.title: Home Depot Says Homeowners Are Weary From Economic Pressures
item.description: The retailer said same-store sales were nearly flat as homeowners shied away from big-ticket projects amid worries about housing costs and the job market.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Daniel Cole/Reuters
item.media:description: Home Depot has seen “significantly reduced demand for projects and other purchases associated with buying and selling a home,” its chief financial officer said.

item.title: Trump’s New Tariffs Could Face Legal Challenges
item.description: Critics are questioning the legality of the provision President Trump has used to replace his previous slate of tariffs, raising the prospect of yet another legal battle.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: As the president takes steps to resurrect his tariffs, his chief legal foes are mulling their own options.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Are Adding Steel Mill Jobs, and Crushing American Factories
item.description: Tariffs unaffected by President Trump’s Supreme Court loss are adding costs for many U.S. manufacturers that use steel, limiting exports and jeopardizing jobs.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.media:credit: Bryan Birks for The New York Times
item.media:description: News that the Granite City Steel factory in Granite City, Ill., was rehiring laid-off steel workers was hailed as a sign of industrial revival.

item.title: Trump Officials Seek to ‘Reimagine’ Unemployment Benefits, Targeting Fraud
item.description: Federal officials are subjecting some states to higher scrutiny in an antifraud campaign, as the president rails against California and states led by Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s efforts to make broad changes to unemployment insurance have raised concerns among groups that support the aid.

item.title: Supreme Court Sides With Couple in Case Involving Baby Food Sold at Whole Foods
item.description: The court agreed to revive a lawsuit by a Texas couple who claimed that tainted baby food purchased at Whole Foods had sickened their young son.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Texas couple sued a baby food manufacturer and the grocery chain Whole Foods, arguing that food bought at the store had harmed their young son.

item.title: More Than Half of Teens Use Chatbots for Schoolwork, Survey Finds
item.description: A new study from the Pew Research Center finds teenagers think chatbot-assisted cheating has become “a regular feature of student life.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Ysa Pérez for The New York Times

item.title: Storm Leads to a First for The Boston Globe: A Day Without a Paper
item.description: The company said the blizzard had made it too treacherous for workers to make it to the printing press on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: John Tlumacki/The Boston Globe, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Boston Globe’s printing press in Taunton, Mas., in 2017.

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Go Into Effect at 10 Percent, Not 15
item.description: The change surprised executives and foreign leaders, who had been expecting the 15 percent rate the president announced on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shipping containers in Miami last year. Within hours of the Supreme Court ruling on Friday, President Trump said he would impose a 10 percent tariff globally to replace the ones the court had ruled against.

item.title: Corporate America’s Growing Quest for Tariff Refunds
item.description: Thousands of companies are expected to follow FedEx’ in suing the government to recoup levy payments, after the Supreme Court overturned the tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly and Brian O’Keefe
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: FedEx is the latest, and one of the most prominent, companies to sue for a “full refund” of tariffs.

item.title: Paramount Revises Its Bid for Warner Bros. Discovery
item.description: If Warner Bros. deems Paramount’s latest bid superior, Netflix would have four days to make a counteroffer.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Ricardo Nagaoka for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paramount had until the end of Monday to submit its best and final offer for Warner Bros. Discovery, which previously announced a deal with Netflix.

item.title: Racing to Catch Up With Nvidia, AMD Signs Chips-for-Stock Deal With Meta
item.description: The multibillion-dollar deal is AMD’s latest move to catch up to Nvidia in the lucrative world of selling artificial intelligence chips.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle and Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Steve Marcus/Reuters
item.media:description: Lisa Su, AMD’s chief executive, has been trying to break into a market for A.I. chips that has been dominated by Nvidia.

item.title: I.R.S. Tactics Against Meta Open a New Front in the Corporate Tax Fight
item.description: The agency is using real-world profit data to challenge how big companies value offshore intellectual property.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Drucker
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Washington headquarters of the Internal Revenue Service, which says Meta owes nearly $16 billion in back taxes and penalties.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.description: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Ben Jones; Source Photographs by Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times; Loren Elliott for The New York Times; Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: FedEx Sues for Refund of Trump Tariffs Rejected by Supreme Court
item.description: The company, which did not specify how much it was seeking, is expected to be one of many demanding compensation for levies ruled unlawful.
item.dc:creator: Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some analysts say the tariffs ruled illegal by the Supreme Court last week had raised as much as $175 billion.

item.title: Pentagon Summons Anthropic Chief in Dispute Over A.I. Limits
item.description: The artificial intelligence company has demanded that some guardrails be put in place as it negotiates a contract with the Defense Department.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, the chief executive of Anthropic, will meet with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at the Pentagon.

item.title: After Saks Bankruptcy, Richard Baker Says He Saved Luxury Department Stores
item.description: Richard Baker wanted to create a retail empire when he combined Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus. About a year later, it filed for bankruptcy.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman, Lauren Hirsch, Jacob Bernstein and Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Dina Litovsky
item.media:description: Richard Baker at the Saks Fifth Avenue flagship store in New York City in 2023. The chain’s parent company entered bankruptcy last month.

item.title: More Than Half a Million Customers Have Lost Power on East Coast
item.description: The outages were mostly caused by problems with local power lines, and coastal Massachusetts was particularly hard hit.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Jenna Russell
item.media:credit: Lucy Lu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nearly 300,000 electric utility customers in Massachusetts were without power at noon on Monday.

item.title: Trump Administration Scrambles to Pick Up the Pieces of Broken Tariffs
item.description: President Trump is already working to piece his tariff program back together, after a Supreme Court ruling ruptured a centerpiece of his economic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has said that tariffs will help America’s manufacturing sector and create factory jobs, though many economists have questioned those claims.

item.title: Binance Employees Find $1.7 Billion in Crypto Was Sent to Iranian Entities
item.description: Binance pledged to crack down on crime. But internal investigators at the world’s largest crypto exchange continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on the platform.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Forsythe
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Binance, the world’s largest venue for crypto trading, has continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on its platform, even after it pleaded guilty to breaking anti-money-laundering laws in 2023.

item.title: Tariff Turmoil Returns to Global Markets
item.description: Businesses and U.S. trade partners are again grappling with the uncertainty of President Trump’s trade war, even as he imposes new levies.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Ian Mount and Grady McGregor
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said the Supreme Court’s decision overturning many of his tariffs wouldn’t derail his trade policy — but potential hurdles are emerging.

item.title: Top Fed Official Sees Little Effect on Rate Outlook From Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.description: Christopher J. Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he would support a pause in rate cuts in March if the labor market continued to show signs of stabilizing.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Brendan McDermid/Reuters
item.media:description: Christopher J. Waller, a governor at the Fed, on Monday acknowledged the extreme uncertainty around President Trump’s tariffs.

item.title: Thousands of Flights Are Canceled as Storm Slams Northeast Airports
item.description: Airlines suspended operations at some major airports and expect to restart some flights on Monday and more on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi and Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
item.media:credit: Dakota Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Snow-covered parts of a runway at Newark Liberty International Airport on Sunday night.

item.title: U.K., Australia and Others Worse Off Under Trump’s New Tariffs
item.description: Many important U.S. trading partners are facing higher duties after President Trump, reacting to a Supreme Court setback, set the rate on a new set of global tariffs at 15 percent.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson and Aaron Krolik
item.media:credit: Phil Noble/Reuters
item.media:description: A Jaguar Land Rover factory in Solihull, England. The automaker sells about a fifth of its cars in the United States.

item.title: What’s Happened Since the Supreme Court’s Tariff Ruling
item.description: After the Trump administration’s punishing tariffs were invalidated, the president said he would impose new tariffs using a different authority. It’s been a whirlwind.
item.dc:creator: Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court on Friday, in a 6-to-3 ruling, found that the statute that President Trump invoked to bypass Congress did not allow him to unilaterally impose tariffs.

item.title: Fact-Check: Trump’s Latest Claims on Jobs, Inflation and Crime
item.description: Trends on jobs, inflation and crime that began before Donald Trump retook office continued, largely unabated, in his first year back.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Cai and Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking in Rome, Ga., last week.

item.title: Supreme Court Considers Fate of Docks and Other Assets Seized by Cuba in 1960
item.description: Amid rising tensions with Cuba, the Trump administration is backing lawsuits that would allow Americans to get compensation for property confiscated by Fidel Castro’s regime.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Havana Docks Company
item.media:description: Revolutionaries confiscated the property of the Havana Docks Company in 1960.

item.title: Homeownership Is Out of Reach for Many Americans, Despite a Buyer’s Market
item.description: A growing split between low-to-middle-income families and wealthy households is changing who has access to homeownership now.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashlan and Kai McDaniel would love to buy their first home, but feel that market forces aren’t on their side. “It feels very overwhelming,” Ms. McDaniel said.

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is Trending in Schools. Here’s Why.
item.description: Artificial intelligence companies are urging teachers to prepare students for an “A.I.-driven future.” What that means varies from school to school.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at North Star Academy Washington Park High School in Newark can use A.I. chatbots to explore career pathways or hone their writing skills.

item.title: Need an Outfit? Pickle Clothing Rental App Helps Users Stay on Trend.
item.description: Pickle, a new peer-to-peer apparel-rental app, helps users stay on trend without having to go into debt or rely on climate-unfriendly fast fashion.
item.dc:creator: Kasia Pilat

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is the New Drivers’ Ed at This Newark School
item.description: Teachers say they want to equip high school students to drive artificial intelligence, rather than be mere passengers steered by chatbots.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: In February, North Star Academy Washington Park High School started a new A.I. class for seniors.

item.title: From Sundance Director to Head of Film Forum
item.description: Tabitha Jackson sees an opportunity to develop the next generation of cinephiles at the Greenwich Village art-house cinema.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: Under her leadership, Jackson said, “The most important thing is to make sure that Film Forum continues its mission.”

item.title: Trump Calls on Netflix to Oust Susan Rice From Its Board
item.description: The president made the attack as Netflix and Paramount Skydance face a key deadline in a bidding war for Warner Bros. Discovery.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Susan Rice, who worked in the Clinton, Biden and Obama administrations, joined the Netflix board in 2018, left in 2020 to work in the Biden administration, and then joined again in 2023.

item.title: Trump Aides Project Confidence on Tariffs After Court Loss
item.description: Administration officials maintain that they can replicate the sky-high duties recently invalidated by the Supreme Court.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm, Alan Rappeport and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Through a new 15 percent global tariff that President Trump announced on Saturday, the administration looked to project confidence that the legal setback would not deter its brinkmanship on trade.

item.title: They Did Deals With Trump to Get Lower Tariffs. Now They Are Stuck.
item.description: Countries that under the threat of tariffs made commitments like enormous investment pledges face the reality that they might have been better off waiting.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi of Japan signing trade and mineral deals in Tokyo in October.

item.title: Should I Tell My Housekeeper, ‘I’m Here for You’?
item.description: Plus, what to do when your job interviewer spouts off on things better left unsaid.
item.dc:creator: Max Read
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Margeaux Walter for The New York Times

item.title: Trump’s Challenge to Free Market Capitalism
item.description: Stakes in private companies. Handshake deals with chief executives. The president’s economic policy has drifted far from principles that long defined the Republican Party. Is it capitalism at all?
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Nicolas Ortega

item.title: A Roving Reporter on the Future of Transit in New York City
item.description: “A lot of interesting things happening in the city involve how people get around,” said Stefanos Chen, a Metro reporter and lifelong bus aficionado.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stefanos Chen, a former real estate reporter, covers New York City’s mass transit for the Metro desk at The Times.

item.title: New York Nurses’ Strike Ends After 6 Weeks as Last Holdouts Approve Deal
item.description: Workers at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia hospital voted for a contract with raises and layoff protections, meaning more than 4,000 nurses will return.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: At its height, the strike by New York City nurses included nearly 15,000 workers.

item.title: What Travelers Need to Know About the Blizzard
item.description: A major winter storm brought heavy snow and widespread cancellations across much of the Northeast. We’ve got advice for stranded travelers.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Hiltner and Kim Bhasin
item.media:credit: Angelina Katsanis for The New York Times
item.media:description: An industrial snow-melting machine at LaGuardia Airport in New York after a major snowstorm in January.

item.title: Trump’s Trade Gamble Will Continue, Despite Supreme Court Rebuke
item.description: The president seems as intent on tariffs as ever and argues that his trade agenda is succeeding, despite little evidence to support it
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump signed an executive order in April that imposed tariffs on countries around the world. The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that Mr. Trump had exceeded his authority.

item.title: JPMorgan Admits to Debanking Trump After Jan. 6 Capitol Attacks
item.description: Nation’s largest bank, in response to a lawsuit filed by the president, confirmed his longstanding complaint about “debanking.”
item.dc:creator: Rob Copeland
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: The JPMorgan Chase headquarters in Midtown Manhattan late last year.
